ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course exposed me to many different religions and understandings of the world.
I learned so many different perspectives on life and really was able to engage with a lot of the course material. Max was absolutely amazing!
I learned how to read and engage with religious and philosophical texts
I learned about different traditions and religions around the world, and their visions of a life worth living.
More firsthand knowledge of major world religions. In terms of personal perspective it wasn't life-changing.
many different cultures
perspectives of different religions/thoughts on how they view a life worth living
I learned about some of the main world religions (Buddhism, Islam, and most of all Judaism and Christianity).
I learned how to successfully look and learn about different global religious perspectives
This course taught me about different worldviews of a life worth living. It has allowed me to self-reflect on what I value in life and how I can achieve a meaningful life.
I learned about many different perspectives regarding what people value in life. This gave me lots of new insights as to how I should live my life and encourage others to live.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was very engaging and I enjoyed the seminar aspect of it. I think I got a lot out of it and am very glad I took the course.

Everything was very helpful and structured for student learning. Max did a great job of maintaining organized discussions and student interaction during class. It made you want to interact with the material and throw in your personal experiences too. No weaknesses I could even think of.
As a survey-style course, the depth of engagement with any particular worldview was limited. I also wish more students in my class had participated actively.
Strengths: TAs are very caring and enthusiastic, I appreciated the time they spent on the course. Weaknesses: Discussions could be a little dry.
seminar style is a strength; weakness is the breadth / lack of depth of inquiry into each tradition

strengths: discussion based, explores a range of perspectives, guest lecturers
weaknesses: impossible to dive too deep into any one section

The papers are a plus. I think they are a good time to sit down and reflect on what's valuable. I strongly disagree with the imbalance in the syllabus--this was a comparative religion course disguised as a general humanities, which made me very uncomfortable with contributing to discussion in class throughout the semester. There was also a lot of readings that were, for the most part, not illuminating at all--many times I found myself wondering why I was reading 70 pages of one sentence after the other saying why God is so great.
Maybe better structured seminars for discussing the readings so there was no awkward silence.

This course was great for facilitating interesting discussion and engaging in productive commentary on a variety of religions, practices, and views. I honestly do not have many ideas for improvement, which is a testament to the organization and depth of the course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would. Max DuBoff was an amazing teacher and taught the material in a super interesting and analytical way. I really enjoyed his course.

Absolutely, this class was a great way to think about life at Yale, before Yale, and after Yale. It helped me get a better sense of what I am looking for post-grad and Max was a huge part of the success of this class. He allowed for an open and free space for students to share their ideas and help each other learn, explore, and plan for what is to come in life.

I would recommend this course! It is not a comparative religion and philosophy class, so if that's what you are looking for, you might want to take a different class. It is geared more toward understanding your own worldview than comparing others.

Yes, with some hesitation -- I think the quality of this course depends on the quality of discussions in section, so you should definitely shop first and see if you enjoy the discussions first. I personally still enjoyed the course, but it wasn't as illuminating as I thought it would be, probably because many of the readings were hard to understand and our discussions of them were a bit surface-level. Max was a very kind and enthusiastic section leader though.

Honestly it's very dependent on the section (leader + other students), but from my experience I don't think I would recommend it. I was warned coming into the course that it would be a lot of navel-gazing, but I decided to go for it anyway because I enjoy self-reflection; however, now I see what people meant. The discussions felt like they had very low stakes (i.e., completely theory and not practice-oriented in terms of what ideas might look like in our own life), and the organization of the course was such that we could not often get deep into the ideas of each tradition, instead skimming over major ideas at a surface level. Hyped but skippable course.

yes. i always left the class with something to think about and definitely found myself thinking about and talking about topics we discussed in class. i feel like i have a stronger definition of my purpose in life after this class
No as long as the syllabus is not made more secular. If you're a religious person you'll have a good time though.
Yes! Great course for simply just learning and taking in information.

Absolutely. As a STEM major, this was a welcome change in my course load. The readings were relevant and uniquely interesting, the essays had appropriate and entertaining prompts, and my TF was great at guiding conversation.
